title: former miss uk playboy bunny
story: NewsFormer Miss UK and Playboy bunny battling cancer told brain tumour is inoperableKerri Parker, , was diagnosed with brain cancer in  and had undergone successful surgery - before being told the tumour had ed and spreadShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  JAN NewsKerri has been told her tumour is now inoperable "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former Miss UK and Playboy bunny who is battling cancer has been told the devastating news that her brain tumour is inoperable. Kerri Parker, , was diagnosed with brain cancer in , but after undergoing surgery to remove the cancer, was given the all clear in . However, the ex Playboy bunny, from Dereham, in Norwich, has now been told the tumour has ed and spread - making it inoperable. Kerri, who lived in the playboy mansion in  and remembers Hugh Hefner like a grandad, has chosen to first seek alternative treatment before starting chemotherapy. Doctors have given the -year-old eight weeks to treat the cancer alternatively before she must start six cycles of chemotherapy and one year of radiotherapy to save her le.   The model, who is also a stunt double, has opted for alternative treatment to avoid spending a year in hospital and losing her career. Kerri has so far been using cannabis oil since learning of her second diagnosis and has found treatment at a clinic in the US that offers a drug with less side effects. The ex-army medic will visit the clinic for the first time in February and will thenfor treatment every six months. Through pageants, fundraisers and putting her house on the market, Kerri has managed to raise enough money for the first six weeks of alternative treatment. She said: Im using cannabis oil and the cannabis has stopped my seizures. Ive noticed that it has helped and in the US they put it all down to alternative treatment.   The -year-old endured an eight-hour operation to remove a cm tumour from her brain after being diagnosed in . Despite being given a % chance of survival at the time, Kerri made a full recovery and threw herself back into work and martial arts training. The former lab technician is a black belt in karate and has continued to work and train throughout her five-year battle with cancer. Kerri said: Im training three times a day at the moment and I have competitions coming up. Ive got a lot on this year and I want to do it all and be well for it.  The model also runs the Kerri Parker Academy , one of the UKs largest modelling schools, offering advice to girls that are about to enter the modelling industry. After hearing the news, the girls at KPA threw a surprise party for Kerri to show their love and support for their role-model before she starts her treatment.Kerri continues to raise money for her alternative treatment through a Facebook fundraising page and has raised almost half of the pound, in just  days.

title: grieving pupils beautiful coffin gesture
story: NewsGrieving pupils beautul coffin gesture to headteacher who wrote deathbed letterPrimary school head Sue East drew a -strong crowd to her funeral, where former pupils sang in her memoryShareCommentsByFred Nathan:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsThe family of Sue East carry her coffin adorned with her pupils drawings "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA primary school head who died after writing a farewell letter to pupils from her deathbed has been laid to rest - in a coffin covered with their drawings. Beloved Sue East was just  when she passed away on December  following a short battle with cancer. On the day she died, she penned a heart-wrenching final letter to her pupils, telling them she was going to die soon and thanking them for their joy and friendship. In the letter, Mrs East quoted a passage from C.S Lewis  novel, The Voyage of the Dawn Treader, comparing death to sailing over the horizon in a small, round boat.   At the end of the letter, she wrote: Never forget there is fairy dust to be found in every situation, no matter how dficult. And last week, almost  pupils, parents, ex-pupils and staff members crammed into Bath Abbey to say farewell to the former headteacher of St Andrews Church School in Bath. Past and present pupils of the school sang at the funeral, and covered Mrs Easts coffin with drawings of fairies, butterflies, love hearts, rainbows and fairy dust.  Tributes paid by pupils said that they loved their headteacher, and described her as: Fun, lovely, exotic, glittery, the best teacher, kind, caring, taught us to believe in ourselves, sprinkled fairy dust everywhere. Her colleagues described her as an extraordinary friend and colleague, and bonkers, as all brilliant people are. Describing her pupils in her letter as wonderful creatures Mrs East said: I have loved my time at St Andrew’s. It’s an amazing school and you are all amazing children. I never thought that I could find so much joy in my work.  Thank you all for sharing your joy and friendship with me. Now it will soon be time for me to move on to new adventures. Teachers discussed the letter with pupils in December and the school has offered support to children and familes.

title: inside lives last family ghost
story: NewsInside lives of last family on ghost estate after ALL their neighbours move outThe last family moved out of Holcombe Close estate in Salford, Manchester, nine years ago, leaving the Wilson family isolatedShareByDamon Wilkinson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsDemonique and Thabo Wilson, pictured outside their home with their five children "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe last family left on an abandoned ghost estate have revealed they live in fear after years of regular break-ins and vandalism. Demonique and Thabo Wilson, from Salford, Manchester, say their five children have gradually been left with no friends to play with.They also claim their bins have not been collected for six years, forcing them to take their rubbish to the tip themselves. And because, they say, nobody would buy their home, they are now stuck in limbo, the Manchester Evening News reports. The last of the Wilsons  neighbouring families moved out of Holcombe Close in Pendleton nine years ago amid a pound million regeneration project.  All of the familys neighbouring properties on the small ghost estate have been either torn down or cleared out, and just one row of six terraced houses remain. Five of those have been boarded up, and the Wilsons claim they can no longer even access basic services from their local authority. But council bosses say the reason the familys bins do not get collected is because they dont leave them out. Mr Wilson told the MEN that he has lost count of the number of times his family has been targeted by vandals and burglars . Rats and bats allegedly entering their home from nearby abandoned properties also pose a constant headache for the family of seven. Mr Wilson, , a mental health nurse and trainee church minister, claimed: We suffer. Weve had our windows smashed, the car vandalised. Ive lost count of the amount of times weve called police . There is no-one for the kids to play with. Normal kids they have friends in their neighbourhood. Our eldest children, their friends have all moved. Our youngest children think this is normal because its all theyve known. But its not normal. It has to be brought to the publics attention so more families dont suffer like we have. The Holcombe Close falls under the remit of the Pendleton PFIproject, a -year regeneration project which will come to approximately pound million. The Wilsons are in the middle of a long-running legal battle with Salford City Council, which they claim has breached their human rights by not offering them a new-build house as a replacement. Six years ago, a judge ruled in their favour, although the case was later put on hold following an appeal by the council. The family is currently unable to sell their home to a private buyer, and refuse to sell to the council until they are guaranteed another council property in the area. Mrs Wilson, , said: We do not feel safe here, our kids do not feel safe. They do not have neighbours. There is no-one for them to play with. We feel like we are on our own. We cannot sell to a private buyer, because we are attached to five derelict houses that the council want to demolish. Nobody would buy this home, so we are limbo. We are stuck.  We are paying our council tax, but we are not even getting basic services like getting our bins collected. We have to take our rubbish to the tip. What are we paying for  Councillor Tracy Kelly, the lead member for housing and neighbourhoods at Salford City Council, said: “We need to buy this property as part of a poundmillion regeneration scheme which started in . The whole area needs to be cleared and replaced with a mix of brand new up-to-date homes which will cater for local needs which includes homes for families, people with disabilities and those who need affordable housing. “Every effort has been made to agree a value for the property and find suitable alternative accommodation for the resident. This has included offers of new and refurbished rented accommodation in the area which have been rejected. We will continue to work with the family to find a satisfactory resolution. Holcombe Close receives the same service as the rest of the city but no bins are left outside the property.

title: mum eight jogged past horror
story: NewsMum-of-eight jogged past horror crash - without realising husband had been killedJacqui Saunders, , tried to ring her husband John to tell him hed had a "lucky escape" - but then discovered he hadntShareCommentsByAnna Whittaker:,  JAN NewsJacqui Saunders has paid tribute to her kind-hearted and honourable husband John "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum-of-eight has revealed how she ran past the scene of a horror crash - without realising her husband had been killed in it. Brave Jacqui Saunder tried to ring her partner John, who should have been at work, after coming across the devastating scene. She told Derbyshire Live: I thought I should ring him to say you’ve had a lucky escape, only to find he hadn’t, it was him. The heartbroken mother has now paid tribute to her kind-hearted and honourable husband following the tragedy last month.At the time he died, John and his family had been looking forward to Christmas, with his presents already under the tree.Daughter Kirsty Saunders also paid tribute to her dad, saying: I wish hed just come down the drive. He always texted me on a Friday night saying Good night, God bless you so thats my last message from him. John, from Loscoe, Derbyshire, died when his moped was involved in a collision with a Range Rover on December . Jacqui, who was married to him for more than  years, explained how she wasrunning that morning and was directed around the accident. Born inKirk Hallam, John worked as a telesales manager at SC Johnson in Denby, was described as a kind-hearted enthusiast who loved lorries and Titanic. The couple met in a pub in Eastwood and later married in June . Housewe Jacqui, , revealed how John took on her five-year-old daughter Anna, which was a huge thing. Four boys and three girls followed, including their youngest, who is now .  Jacquisaid: It was never a plan to have a big family but when we had a loft conversion it just went from there. He wasalways a gentleman who wouldn’t let you walk on the roadside. We could talk for hours and never ran out of things to say. Le wasn’t perfect but at the moment the good outweighs any of the bad. The best memory Ive got is him taking me to see Bryan Adams. Its not the sort of thing we ever did but it was on my bucket list and he surprised me with tickets. It was our biggest date night ever. Johnsmum Gwyn, said: John always went for a drink with his dad every Saturday night after he moved out. When his dad passed away five years ago I went out with him every Saturday. It sorted out the week. John was an honourable man and he was very honest. He had a very deep faith. Kirsty, said her dad always made time for all of us inidually.  She said: Hed always giveme a hug when I came in. Its those moments I miss the most. Eldest child Anna ,, said: After a long engagement, Im glad that we finally had the wedding, so that Dadhas beenable to see one of his children get married. She added: Fathers Day  was the last time the whole family were together because we all have busy lives so very rarely all got together at the same time. All the partners came and the grandkids were there too. We had to force everyone to take a photo but Im so glad we did. Jacqui said the support from the community has been amazing following her beloved husbands death. She said: Everyone has rallied round and supported each and every one of us and still continue to do so. We cant thank them enough. We are supporting each other as a family and hed be so proud to know weve come together. We miss him terribly and he didnt deserve this tragic ending. Despite the messages of condolence from around the community, the familysaid they feel theyve had little support from the police.  They said: We had to ring the police to organise for them to come over. We were handed abooklet and that was it really. Weve seen one police officer in a month. A spokesperson at Derbyshire police said: At Derbyshire Constabulary we endeavour to support all families who have been bereaved as a result of road traffic incidents. “On this occasion the family of Mr Saunders have not received the support they were expecting and for that we apologise. “Officers have been in touch with the Saunders family and have agreed a course of action as enquiries continue.” The family added that the Coroners Court in Derby rang them  minutes before Johns inquest opening started. Jacquisaid: They said they had a slot, so they were taking it and I could be thereI wanted to be. I couldnt go because I was  minutes away so I told them to go ahead. A spokesperson at Derby Coroners Court said: The court room was in use quite a lot last week. We had a slot available and we gave [the family]  minutes notice. We were informed by the family to go ahead. It was short notice but we have limited resources. They family will now be formally invited to the inquest hearing when the coroner gives a verdict.

story: NewsBreeder shocked as mutant goat born with two heads, four eyes and three earsThe kid, which was unable to stand and needed to be bottle fed, died four days later during cold weather in Yezhai, eastern ChinaShareByKelly-Ann Mills:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news weird-news video mutant-goat-born-two-heads-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn animal breeder was shocked when one of his goats gave birth to a mutant kid with two heads, four eyes and three ears. The mother was in labour for seven hours before onlookers had step in and help deliver the new arrival. Chinese Breeder Gao Dafa said he had to assist by pulling the oddly-shaped kid out. It was born on Sunday, January  - but was unable to stand.   The animal, which needed to be bottle fed, was able to suckle from both its mouths and could see through all four eyes. Its condition is believed to have been caused by a genetic mutation during development.

story: Dundee Elite Freestyle Kickboxing Fight School have their first competition of the year this weekend.The club will head down south next Sunday to take part in the Watford Open Nationals .An eight-strong fight squad of coach Sean Wanless, his son Riley, Derren Currie, Cameron and Lennon McGregor, Thomas and Nathan Armstrong and Aaron Humphries will take to the ring for the Dundee outfit.Dundee Elite have been back in training for a fortnight ahead of ato competitive action as they seek to build on a terric  for their athletes with more medal success.And Wanless has been happy with how their preparations have been going so far ahead of the meet as they look to shake off the cobwebs from the winter break.“We have been back for a couple of weeks since the new year and we are putting them through some tough sessions,” the -year-old said.“They are nowhere near as fit as they used to be but they’re still giving it %, which is good to see.“We will be ready for the tournament, can’t wait for it in fact!“We have got the Scottish Championships coming up but we have decided to go to Watford to see what they have got down south.“We’ll get dferent opponents, which is good, and we’ll give it a good go.“I am hoping for and expect medals.“We then head for the WKA champs two weeks after that.”The competition will see the debut of young Humphries for the club and Wanless is delighted to see more kids taking up the sport with Dundee Elite.He added: “He was at another club and has only recently joined us.“It will be his first fight for the club and he is a cracking wee fighter.”

title: dundee uniteds aidan nesbitt says points more important than impressing mark ogren
story: New boy Aidan Nesbitt admits the need for three points and not any desire to impress watching owner Mark Ogren was what drove Dundee United to their - victory over Dunfermline.Prior to kick-off on Saturday, the photographers’ lenses were trained on the directors’ box at Tannadice and not the pitch as US millionaire Ogren took his seat for the first time since buying the Tangerines last month.His arrival had staff at United on their toes and manager Robbie Neilson expressing the hope his team would give their new supremo a win to welcome him.Nesbitt, though, insists the chance to boost promotion hopes was all that concerned the players as they ran out.“We were not thinking about the owner being there massively,” said the -year-old.“Before a game you are concentrating on the performance, your role, what you have to do tactically.“We have games Saturday to Saturday and sometimes even on a Tuesday. All you are really thinking about day-to-day is the next game and getting three points.“Maybe afterwards there will be people talking about it and you are pleased you’ve got a win for him because it is the first time he’s been here.“Before a game, though, it’s not something we’re thinking about.”And,Nesbitt and his team-mates would have liked to have played better in front of the man who pays their wages, he believes the owner could take encouragement from the way United battled for three big points.In danger of being detached at the turn of the year, back-to-back defeats for Ross County and Ayr have left United just one win off the pace in the battle for automatic promotion.And,the former Celtic kid would have liked to have put on a better show for everyone who was at Tannadice, he knows getting the job done mattered most.“Three points and the results where went our way, that makes it a good day.“It was, obviously, a bit of a battle but we got there in the end and that’s what matters.Performance-wise it wasn’t the best and we would expect to play a lot better than that and put on a show but sometimes circumstances in a game mean it doesn’t go that way and then you need to grind it out and win it.”If Nesbitt was nothing like satisfied with his own display, he had the consolation of knowing for the second week running he played a part in a vital goal.His debut against Partick saw him win the penalty to earn United a point and on Saturday he provided the cross for Nicky Clark’s dramatic late winner.“It’s good to contribute when you’re new and I’ve done that in my first two games.“My game play against Dunfermline wasn’t good enough but to make contributions is important andI’m still making those contributions when I’m playing better I will be happy.”In setting up the all-important goal, Nesbitt showed character. He had not been happy with his performance but he wasn’t going to hide.“I had a pass that went nowhere and, before the goal, a cross that went right to their keeper.“When that happens you can put your head down and go into a shell, especially in a game like that one but you just need to keep going, believe in yourself.“I kept going and when I saw Cammy I cut it back to him. It came back out to me and I saw a couple of boys running. Nicky made a brilliant run and when I saw him I just put it in that area and let him meet it. He’s done that and finished brilliantly. It was scrappy but one good ball and one good header and it’s a good day.”

title: dundee uniteds sam stanton does not want to experience another scottish cup shock
story: Sam Stanton has been on both ends of cup shocks in his time, and it’s the feeling when he was on the wrong end of one that makes him determined to make sure Dundee United win their fourth-round tie against Montrose.As a Hibs player, Stanton was part of the side that made an unexpected exit at the hands of Raith Rovers.That painful memory is one he does not want to experience again.“I’ve actually had good and bad in the cup and, hopefully, this can be another good memory,” said the midfielder.“When I was at Dumbarton, we had a couple of games where we weren’t expected to win and did, so that was a nice feeling.“But, when I was at Hibs, we were beaten by Raith and that definitely wasn’t a nice experience.“They were in the Championship and we were in the Premier League, so everyone expected us to get through. It wasn’t good when we lost.“That feeling is one you don’t want again and results like that one just show you can’t take anything for granted.“Teams in Scotland in all the leagues have good players and,you don’t have the proper approach, you will have problems.”And Stanton expects Montrose to battle tooth and nail to cause a shock tomorrow but believes United will be ready to cope with that.“These are dficult games because you know one team is giving everything they can to beat you because they have that nothing-to-lose mentality about them.“I’ve been there myself in those cup-ties when I was with Dumbarton, where you play teams who are bigger than your club and you don’t normally play against.“It excites you and it’s a chance for you to show how good you are. It’s why,you’re the bigger team, you can never take these games for granted.”He believes the key to avoiding a shock is treating the opposition with the respect they deserve and working towards the tie asit was a big game.“We have prepared for this one like we do every other game and that makes sure you have the right attitude.“The manager has had his videos of Montrose and been telling us about their strengths and weaknesses.“That way you make sure you are going into the game with the right mentality.”And,promotion from the Championship this term is by far the No  goal, Stanton admits he would love to go as far as possible in the cup.“A cup run is always important for the supporters and we know that.“For the players as well, it’s nice to do well and, as a football club, it is always important that we go as far as we can in the cup.“It’s another game we want to win and,you can string some wins together in the league and add a cup run to that as well, it’s always a help.”Stanton is also well aware that a side story tomorrow will be Tangerines legend Sean Dillon coming up against them for the first time since he ended a -year stay at Tannadice in .He expects the man who won the cup with United in  to get a rousing welcome from Arabs but, once that is out of the way and the game kicks off, it will be business as usual.“Sean left before I arrived at United but I know what a good player he was for the club.“He was here a long time and I’m sure he will get a good reception from our fans who travel up there.“For us, it’s about making sure he’s not the one getting clapped off the pitch after the game has finished.”

title: dundee winger andy dales looking to make instant impact
story: Dundee winger Andy Dales is hoping to hit the ground running after checking in at Dens Park on loan from Scunthorpe United.The -year-old former Derby County youth academy product has joined up with the Dark Blues until the end of the season and goes straight into the squad for Saturday’s Scottish Cup fourth-round visit of Queen of the South.It was a deal that was agreed quickly, so much so, the England C international had to race north on Monday morning to complete the move.He has been in training with Jim McIntyre’s men since and is hoping to make his debut at Dens this weekend.“It’s been really good, I had a little chat with the gaffer on Tuesday morning and have had some intense training sessions so I’m really looking forward to it,” said Dales.“I only found out on Monday morning. The gaffer at Scunthorpe pulled me in and just said that there’s an opportunity to go to Dundee for the rest of the season on loan.“And I thought, I want to get as many games under my belt and it’s a great club.“I travelled up on Monday night, which took five-and-a-half hours, so I was a bit stf on Tuesday morning but when I got into it I really enjoyed it.“The boys have been brilliant, I’ve got to know a few of them already and hopefully a few more before Saturday and they seem like a really good bunch so far.”The cup-tie with Championship Queens could also see the debut of former Ross County and Dundee United striker Craig Curran following his move across Tannadice Street.Meanwhile, former Dee defender Steven Caulker has finally found a new club.The England international centre-back, who left Dundee abruptly at the end of the summer transfer window in August, has signed for Turkish top-tier side Alanyaspor on a deal until the end of the season.The -year-old former Liverpool and Tottenham man had been without a club since leaving the Dee, for whom he made  appearances, scoring once.*Dundee have signed a five-year kit sponsorship deal with Italian sportswear company Macron.Macron will supply kit from the start of the   season.

title: jim mclean saddened by the waygoing of tannadice legends
story: It’s always sad when a football legend moves on from a club.However, that is the nature of the game, and spaces have to be freed up for new talent brought in or coming through.I can remember a couple of Dundee United-supporting friends being upset when Andy Rolland left the club.They felt, at that time, he could still do a good job for the team.Signed from Cowdenbeath in , Rolland, nicknamed “The Galloping Major”, would stay for  years at Tannadice.United wanted him to stay on but the player had an offer from American club Fort Lauderdale Strikers.Given his tremendous service in playing well over  games for the Terrors, the club immediately granted him a free transfer in September .He said at the time: “This offer has come right out of the blue.“Fort Lauderdale phoned me on Thursday, wanted me to travel on Saturday, and then play my first game for them on Sunday.“But that was too rushed for me.“I expect to go sometime next week.”He continued: “It’s a great offer, and I had to accept.“However, it’s a wrench leaving United after all these years.“Fort Lauderdale have offered me a -month all-year contract, but I’d rather come home when the main season finishes.”Tannadice manager Jim McLean was sorry to see his full-back go.“We will miss him – off the field as well as on it,” he said.“Since I’ve come into Tannadice, we have now lost three great long-serving players – Dennis Gillespie and Doug Smith being the others.“All of them were outstanding club men, and great examples for our young players.”The Dundee United directors also showed their appreciation of his loyalty by making a special payment to him in lieu of a benefit.On ing from America, where he also turned out for Los Angeles Aztecs, Rolland spent two years with Harry Melrose’s Dunfermline, before ending his playing career back at Cowdenbeath.He also managed the Central Park side for a spell.

title: today is a fresh start for craig curran and it can be for dundee
story: Dundee’s Scottish Cup clash with Queen of the South marks a fresh start for Craig Curran after his move over the road from Dundee United earlier this month.And the striker believes the resumption of hostilities after the winter break can prove exactly the same for the until-now struggling Dark Blues.Having been playing his football just yards away during the first half of the season, the -year-old is well aware of the troubles his new team have gone through.But since he’s been in the door at Dens Park, he’s admits he’s been impressed by his new team-mates and, more importantly, their determination to turn things round.“It’s been brilliant since I came in. I’ve enjoyed it, the lads, the training, everything about it has been good,” said the man who is teaming up again with boss Jim McIntyre after their time together at Ross County.“The fitness levels are really good and the lads are at it. You can see they are up for the fight and there is some really good quality here, there’s no doubt about that, so it’s looking promising.”And the Liverpudlian believes three weeks off has given Dundee the chance to recharge their batteries.“I think the break has been a good thing, mentally in particular. I’ve been in this position and sometimes when you are in that rut when you are finding it dficult to pick up points it’s nice to have that break.“Mentally and physically you get away from it and then you come back in like it’s almost a new season, so I think it has been welcome.“And the mood here has been good but I don’t think I’ve been surprised by that because the lads know there is enough here and we are adding a few more bodies, so we know we have what’s needed.“We are up for a fight and you can see that looking round.”Curran believes that willingness, starting with tomorrow’s cup-tie, to do whatever it takes to get wins will be vital in the coming weeks.“There are times when it’s not going to be pretty because of where we’re at. There is going to be that sense of anxiousness going into games but we have that hunger and drive to overcome that.“There might be games that are ugly but these are ones we need to make sure we go on and win.“Whether we scrap it out - or -, we have to win and, once we do, we can then go and play a bit like I know we are capable of.”If, on paper, Dundee have been handed the perfect opportunity to report back with a win by being paired with a side from the second tier, Curran knows they’ll have to perform to make the next round.His time at Tannadice taught him there are decent outfits in that ision and, after facing them twice, he puts Queens in that category.“This is not going to be an easy game, just because they are in the Championship, no one can think that.“They have boys who are good players – Stephen Dobbie is on fire right now with his goals.“So, the mentality is the one thing we have to make sure is right and that’s not something I think we have an issue with. We have to make sure we come out on top, that’s our aim.”Curran also took the opportunity to stress he left United on good terms and thanked Tangerines boss Robbie Neilson for allowing him to move early in the January window.“I had a good relationship with Robbie and I only have good things to say about him.“The style he wanted was to play with one striker and Pavol Safranko has been the best player at United by a margin, I feel.“I understood that and he understood what an opportunity this move was for me.”

title: tom duthie scottish football should never allow merger of dundees clubs
story: The latest outbreak of merger fever in Dundee was no more than another in a long list of  alarms among the city’s football public.It’s not unlike the hypochondriac who catches a cold and immediately thinks he’s gone down with pneumonia.The revelation Dundee owner Tim Keyes wants to increase his shareholding to over % and remove the right of the club’s supporters’ society to veto any merger with neighbours United, had temperatures running high.With another American, Mark Ogren, now in control at Tannadice, fans of both clubs had been examining the “symptoms” and reached the diagnosis that a coming together was desired.That shows the accusation the media never let the facts get in the way of a good story can also, sometimes, be levelled at supporters.All along a forensic examination of the timeline of those symptoms strongly suggested this had everything to do with Keyes wanting to be able to build his new stadium at Camperdown without having to get the go-ahead from the fans’ group.Moving away from Dens is another on the list of protected items they can block and,Keyes is going to spend millions on “Nou Campie”, it’s not stretching the imagination to see why he might not want to need permission from a group that won’t be asked to inject a penny.More signicant is the fact Dundee first raised the matter months ago – before Ogren was on the scene at United. Even though this was a case of putting two and two together and getting five, it shows, despite merger being mooted and quickly dismissed on numerous occasions down the decades, it remains a worrying subject for the fans.And while those further afield may see a lot of sense in a one-club city, for those punters who actually turn up at Dens and Tannadice, it is the nightmare scenario. They’ll take hard times like financial crisis and relegation and stick with their team but what they’d never do is watch a merged team.That alone is why such a move is too dangerous. The clubs should always take the “nos” of the fans who go to games over the “I woulds” of potential new customers of a ‘Dundee City’.There is every chance a build-it-and-they-will-come merger would leave us with a club only slightly bigger than the two that exist.That wouldn’t just be bad for the city but Scottish football and it makes it surprising that, when the topic is raised, no one at the top of the game has come out against it.While sporting performance is rightly the normal criteria for the make-up of our top ision,ever it was to be done on size of club, Dundee and United would be in there – and comfortably so.If Premiership membership was decided on that second basis the top  would be something like Celtic, Rangers, Aberdeen, Hearts, Hibs, Dundee United, Dundee, Motherwell, Kilmarnock, St Johnstone, Falkirk and St Mirren.The likes of Morton, Dunfermline and Inverness may argue they should be in there but it would be on the basis they have more potential than the names at the end of that list.When it comes to core support, the first seven clubs listed are untouchable. If Glasgow giants Rangers or Celtic, on their own, are bigger than the rest put together, those from the country’s three other major cities are also well ahead of the others below them.To reiterate, in all but exceptional circumstances, results should determine who’s in the top league, so it’s up to the likes of United to get back there by winning matches.But when the Tangerines and the Dark Blues are in the top flight, Scottish football is the better for it.That will always be the case.

title: Broken lift leaves Inverness retirement flats residents stranded
story: RESIDENTS of a retirement complex in Inverness have been left disappointed, disgusted and even frightened by a range of issues which they say goes well beyond simple teething troubles.Problems affecting the Oakwood Court development in Crown ndash which is built on the grounds of the former Inverness Royal Academy building ndash include a lt which has repeatedly broken down, leaving some elderly residents effectively stranded on the upper floors, leaking pipes and badly sealed showers which have resulted in waste water and raw sewage seeping into some flats.The car park is also poorly lit and therefore a trip hazard.Residents of the -flat site are now contemplating legal action against operator McCarthy and Stone.Residents also have concerns about the electric supply and telephone system, with telephone lines not connected or fitted in wrong flats.Resident Paul Wells said problems with the lt were the biggest issue.ldquoWe have  apartments and only one lt, which is totally unreliable, he said.The lt broke down on seven occasions between late August and the end of the year, including four days over Christmas.ldquoSome people just didnrsquot go out of their apartments because of it, it was pretty dismal, Mr Wells said.Mr Wells said there were also safety issues in the car park.ldquoWe have some very uneven surfaces and so far we have had four residents trip over at night because lighting in one part is virtually non-existent, he said.ldquoAs you can imagine, wersquore pretty fed up. We donrsquot see it as being trouble-free living at the moment. We have paid over the odds for our apartments because we were after a certain lestyle and Irsquom sure we will get it, but in the meantime, it is very frustrating and frightening for some of our residents and, in terms of the car park, quite dangerous.The residents raised their concerns in a meeting with McCarthy and Stone management , but remained unsatisfied with the response. They are now speaking to a lawyer about the possibility of legal action, Mr Wells revealed.A spokeswoman for the firm said it was very sorry to hear about the problems, but it had been working hard to resolve defects.ldquoIn line with our commitments to all of our customers, we will ensure that any such faults are rectied as quickly as possible with the minimum of inconvenience, she added, and encouraged customers to raise any concerns with staff.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Demands to tear down Inverness eyesore that has lain empty for 20 years
story: FRUSTRATION is growing among community leaders over a lack of progress to tackle a long-standing eyesore within sight of Inverness Castle.B-listed Viewhill House has stood empty for more than  years and was in poor repair when it was ravaged by fire in .Since then, the roofless shell has remained a carbuncle on the city skyline, shrouded in scaffolding, overgrown bushes and weeds.Pat Hayden, chairwoman of Crown and City Centre Community Council, believes it is time to consider knocking it downthere are no feasible restoration plans for the building ndash once the home of Victorian engineer Joseph Mitchell and later a youth hostel.And a leading city chartered surveyor agreed, saying it was beyond economic repair.Mrs Hayden said the eyesore would ruin the view from the castle once it is turned into a visitor attraction, adding: ldquoThey are going to stand on the hill and look around them, see Viewhill and wonder what on earth it is.ldquoPersonally, I think it should be demolished. You cannot preserve something which is no longer viable. We have waited far too long for something to happen.She is due to meet Highland Council officials later this month to discuss the future of the site.Chartered surveyor Richard Smith, managing director of Allied Souter and Jaffrey, said Viewhill should come down.ldquoIt is worth absolutely nothing unless you get permission to demolish it because the renovation far outweighs its value, said Mr Smith, whose company handled the sale on behalf of the Youth Hostel Association.He also queried its listing which he claimed followed a hurried request from a council official and without a visit from the listings authority.ldquoIt was a bad listing from the point of view that it was not checked out properly, said Mr Smith, who gave a ldquostab-in-the-dark valuation of pound, for the site, based on permission for demolition and redevelopment for a residential property.At one time Viewhill was owned by building firm Ewen Gillies and later acquired by Magnus Propertieswhich is believed to be the present owner. The companyrsquos director has a correspondence address in County Antrim.Highland Council is not in active discussions with the owner and David Haas, Inverness city centre manager, said it was up to the owner to push forward any plans.ldquoAs a council, we recognise the importance of that site and will work with stakeholders who have responsibility for it to develop any opportunities, but at the moment we are not in a position to do that, he said.ldquoObviously, we are very keen to see it brought back into use.Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister agreed action was now needed.ldquoI have spoken to other people who are really fed-up about it, she said. ldquoPeople think it is a disgrace.Highland Historic Buildings Trust previously pressed the case for the restoration and conversion of the property into eight-serviced apartments, but has been unable to raise the costs, estimated at pound. million in .Chairman John Duncan stressed the trust was not the owner or potential developer but got involved to try and find a solution.He said any application for demolition would have to be determined by the council and Historic Environment Scotland.In connection with another controversial Inverness building, aquestionmark hangs over when the former Eastgate Hostel will be demolished, despite previous assurances that eyesore would start to come down next week.Talks took placeon Thursdaybetween Highland Council and representatives acting for the owners of the building which has remained a fire-ravaged eyesore for  days now.Afterwards, neither party would confirm whether work would begin next week, although they insisted the meeting was ldquovery positive.Chiropodist Jim Crawford, whose business is nearby, called for the council to take out a compulsory purchase orderwork does not start by next Friday.ldquoThere has been no sign of activity so far, he said.ldquoIt is an absolute nonsense.Building consultant Gary Johnston, agent for the owners Imtaiz Ali and Mr Cheng, would not confirm when work would begin. All he could say was: ldquoEverything is going according to plan.David Haas, Highland Councilrsquos Inverness city manager, said matters were progressing in a constructive way.ldquoIt is very frustrating it has taken so many years to get to this stage but the principal owner has taken major steps in the last six months, he insisted.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Go ahead for River Ness hydro scheme
story: A SPECTACULAR hydro electric scheme close to the heart of Inverness has been given the green light by Highland Council, and it is hoped it will not only be a source of power, but also an attractive feature on the River Ness.Council officials granted the application for the lsquoArchimedes screwrsquo to be built into the bank next to Holm Mills Bridge near the West Link distributor road but have placed a total of  conditions on the project to safeguard visual amenity, road and pedestrian safety.The project has been warmly welcomed with local councillor Alex Graham, he said: ldquoThis project was first mooted about three years ago and then it came back towards the end of last year. Historically hydro power was generated there in the s in the building that is now the ice-cream shop.ldquoIn the present climate I think it is a very welcome project, one that can not only generate power locally but also become a feature to be enjoyed by visitors and locals.Helen Smith, who is on Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoWe didnrsquot comment on it but it is tucked away quite far from residential buildings. But from my point of view, personally its fine, I remember there was hydro power there in the past and it might be quite attractive. Irsquod be surpriseit bothers any local residents.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Highland arts venue has strategy to combat fund gap
story: THE regionrsquos biggest arts venue has outlined how it must become more financially resilient.In its latest accounts, Eden Court in Inverness reported increased income and more expenditure in the year ending March ,  compared to the previous  months.Last year Eden Court lost pound, a year of funding ndashpound, from Creative Scotland and pound, from the Highland Council.A trusteesrsquo report the figures stated: ldquoThe principal risks identied are financial ones, particularly the effect of this yearrsquos signicant reduction in public funding.ldquoThe organisation must become more financially resilient by growing sources of earned income and building a safe level of reserves.ldquoAs public funding declines, the targets for earnings from trading activities necessarily increase, and the risk that these targets cannot be met also increases. At the same time, our cost base is likely to increase owing to inflationary pressures on resources.ldquoThis year we are working on a strategy for trading through our funding gap, increasing income from charitable trading, reducing costs wherever possible and developing partnerships to share services.ldquoAttention has also been focused on non-financial risks arising from the loss of some channels of regular communication with our major funders our relationship with both Creative Scotland and the Highland Council has been strengthened during the year to March ,  and subsequently.ldquoThe development of positive relationships with funders ndash public organisations and inidual philanthropists ndash remains a high priority and is a central part of Eden Courtrsquos financial strategy for the coming three years.Total income increased from pound,, in  to pound,, last year. For the same period, total expenditure moved from pound,, to pound,,.Total funds also went up from pound,, to pound,,.Advance ticket sales mean that Eden Courtrsquos cash flow position remains strong.The biggest event of the year was the Snow White panto, which sold more than , tickets for its  performances.The report stated: ldquoAttendance for the year has been unprecedented with audiences of , for live performances and , at film screenings. The financial contribution from live performances was pound, higher than budget, boosted by some musical performances in the summer months and an excellent result from our Christmas pantomime.The wholly owned subsidiary Eden Court Trading experienced a rise in turnover from pound,, in  to pound,, last year, and an increase in pre-tax profit from pound, to pound,.The report added: ldquoOver the past four years we have seen substantial growth in trading through our restaurant, cafeacute and bars, and also in sales of confectionary, show merchandise and programmes by our front of house team.ldquoOur trading activities in   resulted in a surplus of pound,, an increase of  per cent over the previous yearrsquos result.ldquoWe will also implement a new strategy to attract philanthropy from trusts and foundations, and from within our community.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Hope that Inverness special needs project can be saved
story: Highland Councilrsquos refusal to fund the Special Needs Action Projectin Inverness has triggered outrage across party lines with councillors and members of parliament queuing up to slam the local authority.Conservative councillor Andrew Jarvie, said: ldquoNot only is this a devastating blow for dozens upon dozens of vulnerable children and young people, it symbolises everything that is wrong with this council administration.Mr Jarvie complained the decision to refuse funding was taken in private, saying: ldquoThis secrecy and behind closed door decisions wreaked havoc on rural communities last year but I find it absolutely disgusting to inflict the same on the most vulnerable people in Highland.ldquoFor SNAP to run such a comprehensive and valuable year round service for pound, a year tells me that they are already managing their funds stringently and that any cut is a gross insult to both the organisation and its users.MP Drew Hendry met with SNAP management last week and he said: ldquoAnybody who knows about the great work SNAP do would also be very concerned by the uncertainty around their future and just how dficult it would be to replace the work that they do.ldquoA better way forward must be to secure their immediate future and to work with them to find sustainable funding for coming years.ldquoThis approach has worked successfully before and I have pledged to do what I can to support SNAP and the council to find a better outcome.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Inverneess Airport announces new flights to Mallorca
story: New flights to Mallorca will be available from Inverness Airport later this year.Theflights operated by JetsGo will fly direct to Palma from Inverness Airport this October, with both flight-only and package deals available.Inverness Airport general manager Graeme Bell said: ldquoTUI has operated very successful flights from Inverness to Mallorca during June and July and Irsquom sure Highland holidaymakers will be delighted to be able to fly directly from Inverness to Palma as it means they donrsquot have a long journey to and from other Scottish airports, saving them time and money.The latest addition adds to an increasingly busy schedule for Inverness Airport.Last month KLM Royal Dutch Airlines announced it is increasing its flights between the Highland capital and Amsterdam to three per day six days a week during the peak summer period.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Inverness schoolgirl coining it in thanks to generous donation
story: AN Inverness schoolgirlrsquos coin collecting hobby has received a boost after she was given a bag of assorted coins by a well-wisher.The man, who insisted on remaining anonymous, came to the Inverness Courier office with the money after we ran a story about Isla MacDonald becoming online coin club Change Checkerrsquos award-winning junior member of .Islarsquos interest in specially minted coins was sparked by the finding of a Girl Guides centenary p and now the Cradlehall Primary pupil has  special p coins and  dferently designed pound coins.Her father Simon helped her to research the first coin and she began keeping an eye out for other coins which are unusual and collectable.Her mother Luisa said: ldquoIt is a shame this man has asked to remain anonymous because we would love to write a thank you letter to him. It was really kind of him. Isla is delighted and fascinated by the selection of coins that was in the bag.Islarsquos coin collection includes several rare items, including coins marking the Commonwealth Games in England, London Underground and Paddington Bear.Like her fellow collectors, she is keeping a sharp eye out for Kew Gardens which remains the most scarce p coin currently in circulation.Among the gted coins is a  pound coin issued to mark  years since the Declaration of Rights being enacted which effectively shted the balance of power from the Crown to parliament and changed the course of British political history.Another is a pound coin which was minted in  to mark the centenary of Entente Cordiale, agreements made between the UK and French governments.Two Cornish halfpennies, and a pound and p from the Isle of Man are also included, as well as a square coin marking the bicentenary of the Battle of Jersey.Although not a coin, the bag included a highly nostalgic ldquoOfficial Licensed Medallion marking that Scotland had qualied for the  World Cup in France. Five World Cups have come and gone since without Scotland managing to qualy.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Loss of Inverness nightclub is sad for the city
story: THE closure of Club Tropicana brings to an end  yearsrsquo experience of working in Inverness nightclubs for Roy Dunnett.However, Mr Dunnett believes the closure is not just sad news for himself and the  colleagues who have been made redundant, but for Inverness as a whole.ldquoInverness used to have three big nightclubs, but now we have city status and a growing student population with the UHI and Inverness doesnrsquot have any, Mr Dunnett said. ldquoThere are plenty of drinking places in Inverness, but we lack a physical nightclub. A lot of stag and hen parties come up to Inverness now and they want to go to a club to finish their night, which they would do back home. They donrsquot want to be in a bar that serves food.Mr Dunnett also worked at Grsquos nightclub on Castle Street, which Club Tropicana owner TGC Leisure closed in May . However, he does not blame the owner for taking the decision to close the clubs but the council for licensing policy changes which allow pubs to remain open until am.ldquoThat put us at a disadvantage, he said.ldquoWe were charging people to get in whereas the bars were free entry. They can also make their money by serving meals during the day. We can only make our money from pm to am.Mr Dunnett also worries about the job prospects for some of his colleagues.ldquoWe employed a lot of single mothers who couldnrsquot work during the day because they couldnrsquot get childcare, he said.ldquoThey canrsquot get jobs in bars because the bars are open during the day.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Poignant tribute to be paid to dedicated Inverness Caley Thistle fan
story: FOOTBALL fans at tomorrowrsquos Scottish Cup tie between Inverness Caledonian Thistle and East Kilbride will be invited to take part in a poignant tribute to a teenager.Caley Thistle supporter Dawn Sinclair should have celebrated her th birthday with a party at the stadium following the game.But sadly Dawn, who had complex special needs, died in Raigmore Hospital on Boxing Day.Donations at her funeral totalled pound which will be given to the hospitalrsquos childrenrsquos unit where she was a regular patient.Dawn, of Holm Park, Inverness, was adopted by Doreen Sinclair and the late John Sinclair when she was two years old and she also had two sisters, Elizabeth and Joanne.Family members will be at tomorrowrsquos Caley Thistle match where fans will be invited to join in applause during the th minute as a tribute to the teenager who wentto games and events organised by supporters.Mrs Sinclair said it would be a moving tribute to Dawn who loved wearing her Caley Thistle strip while her proudest moment was being at Hampden in May  to see the club lt the Scottish Cup.ldquoIt is going to be very emotional but we are also delighted, she said.ldquoI think it is amazing that the club is doing this for Dawn. We have had so many messages of support from people including fans in Glasgow.She recalled Dawn loved the atmosphere at matches.ldquoShe loved the noise and being around lots of people, she said.Although Dawn had a challenging le because of her condition, she enjoyed a iety of activities.ldquoShe loved people and she loved being the centre of attention, Mrs Sinclair recalled.ldquoAlthough she had a lot of problems, she knew what was happening and was very well aware of the day and what time it was and what should be happening.Dawn enjoyed attending Drummond School in Inverness and had been to Belladrum Festival near Beauly and concerts by Ed Sheeran and S Club .Over the years, she became a familiar face on the childrenrsquos unit often being admitted for a chest infection but was unable to overcome illness on the last occasion.She died in Raigmorersquos intensive care unit surrounded by her family.At a celebration of her le, Caley Thistle fans as well as supporters of other teams wore the club colours in recognition of Dawnrsquos love for Caley Thistle.Her hero, club goalkeeping coach Ryan Esson, whom she sponsored, was also among those who attended.Tributes were paid by her sister, Joanne, and childrenrsquos nurses Pam Murray and Laura Steven.Mrs Sinclair said Dawn always received the best of care on the childrenrsquos unit where she was known by many of the staff.ldquoThe care was fantastic, Mrs Sinclair said.ldquoIt is an amazing place.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: Tributes paid to Highland Rugby Club coach
story: TRIBUTES have been paid to a stalwart of Highland Rugby Club following his sudden death.Coach and former player Alisdair Wemyss , known affectionately as ldquoPorky, collapsed and died suddenly on Thursday.All of the Inverness-based clubrsquos matches over the weekend were cancelled as a mark of respect.The clubrsquos head coach, Dave Carson, said he could not believe it when he heard the news from Mr Wemyssrsquos we, Val.ldquoI started playing with him in , he said. ldquoHe was affectionately known throughout Scottish rugby as lsquoPorkyrsquo and he will be a massive loss to the game.ldquoWhen I was appointed first team coach six years ago he was the first guy I brought in to my coaching team. The number of messages of sympathy on Facebook and Twitter from former players and, in particular, props who he coached over the years, has been incredible. He will be sadly missed.The clubrsquos honorary president, Colin Baillie, was also shocked.ldquoComing with the news that our former president Alistair MacCallum also died this week it really is a very sad time for the club, he said.ldquoI coached him at Highland. He was a very positive and aggressive player, playing for the first XV at the age of  and going on to get representative honours with North Midland. Dave Carson brought him on board as a scrummage coach and he did a fantastic job.Former Highland RFC player and musician Bruce MacGregor alsopaid tribute. He said: ldquoHe worked for the council in the lighting department and he really knew everyone. He was always working on traffic lights around town and when he was on the cherry pickers putting up the Christmas lights you would often get a cheery lsquohellorsquo from him.ldquoHe was still playing in the first team when I played around the early rsquos. He was one of the hardest and strongest players on the pitch, but off it was one of the nicest people you could meet.ldquoAs a tight-head prop he passed on his skills to so many youngsters who came through the club teaching them how to improve their technique in the scrum.Among hundreds of comments on the clubrsquos Facebook page from both local fans and other clubs across the country Ian Nixon said: ldquoIt goes without saying that everyone at the club will miss him.ldquoThere was never a dull moment around him.ldquoIn addition to his playing skills and his coaching he was one of the most astute analysts of a match. He saw things that others could not and this made him a most valuable member of the coaching set-up.ldquoPorky you will be sorely missed by all club members and beyond.Monday  Jan  : AM

title: aberdeen held 1 1 by league one strugglers stenhousemuir in scottish cup shocker
story: ABERDEEN were held to an embarrassing - draw against League One part-timers Stenhousemuir in the Scottish Cup fourth round at Pittodrie.Stenhousemuir are rock bottom of Scotland’s third tier but the Dons  failed to see  them off in a frustrating tie.The Dons now face a replay with Stenny  on Tuesday  January  at Ochilview Park .Aberdeen took the lead in the first half through ing on loan Derby County left-back Max Lowe.However they were stunned in the th minute when Mark McGuigan punished poor defending to equalize.Aberdeen made five changes to the side that defeated Livingston - in the final game before the Premiership shut down.New signings Greg Stewart and Max Lowe were both handed starts following the completion of loan deals earlier this week.Attacker Stewart completed a loan deal until the end of the season from Birmingham City.Stewart, who spent last season on loan at Pittodrie, had been on loan at Kilmarnock for the first half of the season and hit impressive form.Birmingham recalled him  from the loan deal at Rugby Park and the Reds swooped to bring him back.With Stewart#s contract set to expire at the end of the season the option will be there to potentially secure Stewart on a permanent deal.Derby County left-back Lowe also made a welcometo the Dons when completing a loan deal for the second half of the campaign.Lowe impressed on loan from the Championship side during the first half of the season but ed to his parent club at the turn of the year.Derby boss Frank Lampard sanctioned a fresh loan deal and Lowe was pitched straight into the starting line-up.There was also a welcomefor Scotland international winger Gary Mackay-Steven who had been sidelined since suffering concussion in the BetFred Cup final on December .Lewis Ferguson ed from suspension whilst Niall McGinn was back after missing the Livingston game with a groin strain.Aberdeen created the opening chance in the fth minute when Shay Logan found Sam Cosgrove in the penalty area with a cross from the right but he fired wide from  yards out.The Dons grabbed the lead in the st minute through a swt passing move that ripped the Stenhousemuir defence wide open.Returning left back LOWE started the move with a pass inside to Stewart who released Graeme Shinnie down the left side of the penalty area.The Reds captain squared a pass back across goal and on loan Derby County full-back LOWE confidently converted from eight yards out.Aberdeen were nearly gted a second goal in the rd minute when a low  yard drive from Cosgrove was fumbled by keeper Graeme Smith.With the ball trundling towards goal centre-back Morgyn Neill hooked it clear.In the th minute Shinnie drove powerfully from the edge of the penalty area but the shot was deflected wide for a corner that came to nothing.In the th minute Andy Considine redirected a Shinnie shot goal wide from  yards out but it was straight at keeper Smith.Moments later McGinn slid a low pass to the onrushing Mackay-Steven who drilled in a powerful  yard shot but keeper Smith did well to block.Soon after McGinn was again involved when he brilliantly brought down a long cross-field ball from Logan on the run before delivering a low cut back into the penalty area.Stewart met it but his low shot from  yards was blocked.Aberdeen were denied in the rd minute when McGinn#s powerful shot from the edge of the penalty area was headed clear by Morgyn Neill.The ball fell as far as Stewart who unleashed a vicious drive that crashed off the under-side of the cross-bar.Stenhousemuir shocked the Dons in the th minute with a leveller as Ruaridh Donaldson was allowed far too much time and space on the left flank to deliver a cross.Striker Mark MCGUIGAN met the cross and unleashed a superb  yard ing header that beat Joe Lewis.Suddenly it was game on.Moments later McKenna rose to meet a McGinn corner kick but his header from  yards flew well wide. At full time the Red Army made their frustration known by booing.ABERDEEN: Lewis, Logan, Lowe, Considine, McKenna, Shinnie, Ferguson, Mackay-Steven, McGinn, Stewart, Cosgrove.Subs: McLennan ,  May ,Subs not used: Cerny, Ball, Gleeson, Wilson, Wright.STENHOUSEMUIR: Smith, Duthie, Munro, Donaldson, Neill, Dickson, McBrearty, Ferry, Cook, Dingwall, McGuigan.Subs: Reid ,Subs not used: McMinn, Vaughan,  Halleran, Garcia Tena, Paterson.Referee:   Barry Cook

story: A Good Samaritan sparked a major rescue operation in a north-east community after hearing cries for help coming from caves.Three search teams were called to the caves at Aberdour Beach at around .pm on Saturday after receiving reports of a person appearing to be in dficulty.However, the teams – two from Fraserburgh and one from Banff – could find nobody matching the description in the report despite searching the area for more than three hours.The Coastguard said they are treating the call as  but with good intent.A Coastguard spokeswoman said: “The Fraserburgh Leboat, Fraserburgh Coastguard Rescue Team and Banff were called to investigate reports of a person in dficulty in the New Aberdour area.“After a y search, nobody was found and the search has ended.”

title: stagecoach launches first bus service on aberdeen bypass
story: Holidaymakers heading for Aberdeen’s airport can make use of new bus routes from today.Stagecoach has revamped its timetable to make it easy for jetsetters to reach Aberdeen International Airport by bus.A new  route has been introduced and will run hourly throughout most of the day between Montrose and Ellon using the AWPR.The service runs from Montrose to Stonehaven before serving Kingswells Park and Ride and the airport. It continues to Ellon and some journeys will also extend to Cruden Bay and Peterhead.Stagecoach has also introduced the  service to link the airport with Portlethen and Newtonhill.A Stagecoach spokesman said: “Residents provided feedback in a timetable consultation requesting a service be introduced to the airport rather than connecting to  in Stonehaven.“On reviewing the feedback Stagecoach has been able to introduce service  shaped by the feedback from these communities.“The  service will operate up to every hour daily to the airport and will also stop at Kingswells Park and Ride.“The park and ride will benefit from both of the new bus services and as a result journeys from the popular Park and Ride site to the airport will be available by bus up to every  minutes, daily.”

In a competitive match, Rangers started strong but Hibernian began to come into the game and whilst both sides had chances, the score remained - at half time. In the second half, Rangers took the lead in  minutes but three minutes later Hibernian drew level.There were few chances in the remainder of the second half and at full time both teams were level at -. Rangers took the lead again in extra time with a deserved winner to secure the cup.Jasmine and Carla came through the Lochgilphead Soccer Centre from primary one age to primary seven, playing in local festivals.In   the girls were important members of the successful Lochgilphead Red Star  team which won the DFDL league cup and finished second in their league. title: marian travels back to the hollow mountain
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsMy book about the project, Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain, was published to coincide with the th anniversary of its opening. Invited to join Cameron up at the Cruachan dam for the second of his two recent programmes, I was delighted to tramp the mighty mountain with Scotland’s Number one authority on outdoor pursuits.As an author and broadcaster, Cameron always has an eye on a good story, and so as well as asking me about the lack of health and safety regulations at the time the hydro project was being built, he also wanted to knowthere really was a murder during the construction. There was, as I told him, a body – but the body wasn’t identied, no arrests were made, no court case took place.It would be a shamethat construction period went down in history as an invasion of , workmen – #Tunnel Tigers# as they were dubbed – into one of Argyll#s most beautul settings and a possible murder.My book was intended to give the story of the local people whose lives were punctuated by this ambitious construction project. Quite rightly, those Tunnel Tigers had been lauded in a number of publications. The work that was done hollowing out Argyll’s highest mountain to provide electricity for the nation was amazing.The plan for Cruachan – as for the other major hydro projects of the post World War II era – was conceived by Tom Johnston, to whom I dedicated my book. Johnston was a politician who remained true to his ideals of bringing rural Scotland into the modern world. There was no power in the Highlands, and without power there could be no industry and no prosperity. The engineering genius was Sir Edward MacColl, whose biographer Norrie Fraser called him #a maker of modern Scotland#.Cruachan was the first reversible pumped-storage system in the world. During its years of construction from  to , eminent international engineers visited the project to see how the water was pumped between two reservoirs through reversible turbine generators. At off-peak hours, the water was – is # pumped back up to the reservoir you see high up in the corrie above Loch Awe, held back by a dam that is now so much a part of our landscape. The loch itself is the lower reservoir.I had imagined that the scale of such a project – using Scotland’s top engineering companies who shipped in workers from other parts of the UK and Europe – would have been a cause for resentment and protest by local people.That, of course, failed to take account of the vision of the folk of Dalmally, Lochawe, and Taynuilt. Although it took men with engineering experience to blast the  miles of tunnels, hollow out the mountain itself, and construct the dam, there was also a need for a support army. There were clerks and porters, joiners and caterers, folk willing to let out a room, a caravan, a house, serve in a pub where just occasionally it was necessary to keep a baseball bat behind the bar to maintain bonhomie. The project kick started careers, fortunes and marriages, and gave the area good roads and a tourist industry.If you haven’t visited the hollow mountain or walked Cruachan’s slopes, make  the year you do.[In bold please] Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain is available from the Argyll Book Centre in Lochgilphead and all good book shops, along with Marian Pallister#s other books of local interest.PICS:The Pass of Brander before work started. no_aCruachanLe before the project # the Loch Awe Hotel with steamers. no_aCruachanThe Queen opening the project in October . no_aCruachanWorking on the  miles of tunnels. no_aCruachanWorking on the road to the dam, overlooking Loch Awe. no_aCruachan

title: farming vital to argyll union chairman tells members
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowTravelling from all corners of the Argyll and the islands, around  members of National Farmers# Union Scotland met in Tarbert for the regional AGM.Members also had the opportunity at Stonefield Castle Hotel to meet and quiz the three candidates for one NFUS vice president position # but more on that in a separate Argyllshire Advertiser story.At the meeting John Dickson continued as regional chairman, with Peter Kennedy from Glendaruel and Duncan Macalister from Glenbarr remaining vice chairmen.In his address to members Bute farmer Mr Dickson described  as #a horrible year# for farmers and crofters across Argyll and the Islands.Despite hopes of a good early spring to ease the fodder crisis from the previous year, what arrived was the #Beast from the East#, a late spring and one of the worst lambings in living memory.A warm, dry and sunny summer failed to undo the damage, leaving many farmers and crofters with depleted bank accounts and resources along with fewer lambs and calves to sell and a lacklustre autumn store trade due mainly to Brexit uncertainty.He added: #Last year I used the phrase #resilient# to describe farmers and crofters in the region. That resilience is running out, and this is particularly true for hill sheep and suckler cow farmers.#And you would think that with the weather we#ve had through  , the results of the lambing and store lamb sales this season we would have a cast iron argument to maintain LFASS support # and to increase it with a top-up for harsh weather. Instead we are faced with a  per cent cut for  and an even bigger cut in .#Claiming that without this #leline support payment# farmers cannot keep going in the high hills, Mr Dickson said NFUS continues to press for a full reinstatement of the LFASS money.#A recent report by the five Highlands and Islands councils shows that Argyll and Bute, Highland, Western Isles, Shetland and Orkney are the most vulnerable to the loss of agricultural support from the EU.#It also shows that we deliver the most benefit in public goods of any region in the UK. We deliver on landscapes, bioersity, air and water quality, cultural heritage, animal health and welfare.#Think how bioersity would be maintained without farmers and crofters managing the grazing land.#In many parts of Argyll you#re lucky to see sheep and cattle grazing. It#s no longer viable, yet without grazing by farm animals the bioersity changes. We end up with wild areas the public cannot access without large amounts of money being allocated to maintain tracks.#In the same report it said that  per cent of tourists came to Scotland for the scenery and landscape. # that#s what you and I provide.#

title: ayr racecourse set stage first
story: NewsAyr Racecourse set to stage first race meeting for humansThe unique event will see Ayrs famous furlongs handed over to runners of a dferent kind.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  JAN NewsLuke Traynor promotes Classic Run at Ayr Racecourse"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAyr Racecourse is breaking with  years of tradition to launch its first race meeting without a horse. Ayr is partnering with the Ayrshire Post for the inaugural Classic Five-Mile Run where human runners of all abilities and ages can follow in the hoofprints of Red Rum. With no jumps to navigate, the going is guaranteed to be good as the route follows a pathed circuit around the one-and-a-half-mile course. Thousands are expected to sign up for the historic run when entries open today for the showpiece five-mile event, the k junior run and the family mile. And with free admission for friends and family plus some great entertainment, there will be no shortage of noise and atmosphere to spur the runners on. Ayr joins Cheltenham, Aintree and Newmarket as the latest racecourse to turn over its track to athletics. World stars Eilish McColgan and Luke Traynor, who have signed up as ambassadors for the Classic Series, reckon iconic Ayr will pull in everyone from elite runners to absolute beginners.  Eilish, who won European m silver last year, said: “This is a brilliant idea to get all the family involved in a new series of runs at exciting new venues. “And I know some runners will be keen to be the first to do all four venues.” Luke, who has his sights set on marathon glory at Tokyo , added: “There is something special about running around such a historic sporting venue. “It’s been done before on motor-racing circuits but this is a first for a racecourse like Ayr. “We spent time working out courses to accommodate all abilities and all ages. “While the five-miler is the headline event, we expect a big entry for the junior and family races.” Gary Fanning, Editor of the Ayrshire Post, said: “‘I’m delighted that the Ayrshire Post is involved in this event and the racecourse is the perfect venue for Scotland’s first Classic Run Series. “It’s a great excuse for our readers to get fit and have a bit of fun while taking part. David Brown, Ayr Racecourse managing director, said his team are gearing up for a big crowd to cheer on the runners on October . He said: “We aredelighted to host the inaugural Ayr Classic Run, which reinforces our reputation as a five-star venue. “The Ayr Classic Run is a great opportunity for all runners, from beginners to elite, to relish the unique experience of running around an iconic course with their families cheering them on. “We are already home to race classics such as The Coral Scottish Grand National and William Hill Ayr Gold Cup. TheAyr Classic Run is a wonderful addition.” Mark Hollinshead, CEO of organisers Hollicom Events, said: “The Classic Run Series is a unique set of innovative running experiences for all the family. “The centrepiece event at each racecourse will attract fun runners, fitness fanatics, fundraisers and club runners alike. “It reflects our mantra: running for all.” The Ayr Classic Run is open to everyone, irrespective of age or ability. All you need to do is decide which of the four events best suits you. The Ayr Classic  Mile Run. From elite athletes and club runners to fun runners, first timers and brisk walkers. Top cash prizes for the winners. The Ayr Classic Junior Run. At k, specially designed for -s. The Ayr Classic Family Mile. For children aged - accompanied by a parent or . Mums, dads, toddlers, grans and granddads are all welcome for a Sunday jog, walk or toddle. The Classic Corporate challenge. You and your workmates can sign up as a four-person team and compete against others for the Ayr Challenge Cup. Who will be the fastest company in Scotland  How to enter Learn more about The Ayr Classic Run by visiting www.theclassicrunseries.
