title: ronnie-spector-on-john-lennon-phil-spector-and-loving-life-at-75
story: Then the song starts. Hal Blainrsquos sticks beat out the rhythm. So familiar, still so fresh.Boom hellip Boom, boom.Boom hellip Boom, boom.The band joins in and then the voice jumps up, cuts through. ldquoThe night we met I knew I needed you so hellipThat voice, so tough, so tender.ldquoSo, wont you, please, be my, be my baby Be my little baby, my one and only baby hellipThis is pop. Then and now and foreverRonnie Spector is in bed when I call. Shersquos not long back from doing a show and right now shersquos having a coffee at home in Connecticut. ldquoIrsquoll go back to sleep after I talk to you, Teddy.It sounds a spartan room. Therersquos a plant she loves and a picture of a Chinese woman in a red outfit. ldquoAnd my TV of course.Therersquos also a calendar on the wall. One that marks all the gigs shersquos played and all the gigs shersquos due to play. Therersquos an X on there that means Glasgow. In a couple of weeks, she will leave her home to travel here to play at Celtic Connections where she will sing the old songs and tell us about the people she knew. Boom hellip boom, boom. Itrsquos why wersquore talking.But, really, wersquore talking because shersquos Ronnie Spector. The voice of The Ronettes. The woman who gave voice to some of Phil Spectorrsquos finest early recordings. The woman who would then marry her producer and go through all kinds of hell until she freed herself and started again.The woman beloved by Springsteen and John Lennon and Martin Scorsese , the woman who was embraced by the American punk fraternity and then namechecked by Madonna. Ronnie Spector. Poprsquos original bad girl . ldquoWe werenrsquot afraid to look hot, she once said of the Ronettes in their s heyday. ldquoThat was our gimmick.Ronnie Spector, now , in her bed drinking coffee and talking to a journalist in Glasgow about the past and the present and finding nothing but good things to say about both.ldquoI was in Glasgow and Scotland a few times in the sixties. I remember the accent was harder than the London accent. I remember the pipers and how they would wear skirts and all that. I remember that well.Read More: Celtic Connections: The Top Ten Must See ShowsIn our time together, she tells me the stories that she tells every journalist about Lennon ndash that time in New York in the s when he saw her in the street and shouted ldquoHey Ronnie Ronette Dick Clarkrsquos Caravan of Stars about that time in the studio when she started singing Be My Baby for the first time and all the musicians just stopped.ldquoIt was like we were in the Twilight Zone. The musicians in the place were going crazy. You remember that feeling how they looked at you and said, lsquoWow, thatrsquos a dferent voice.Theyrsquore good stories, ones we want to hear. But shersquod rather not talk about her ex-husband , thank you. It was  years ago, and shersquos said enough about that. Therersquos a bookyou really want to know, she reminds me.What Irsquom interested in is the before and after of the story. The place where she comes from and the place she is in now, the place she had to fight to get to.The before is easy. Spanish Harlem, Upper Manhattan, at the turn of the s. She makes it sound like paradise.ldquoWhen I was growing up, Teddy, we had everybody in our neighbourhood, so I didnrsquot think about race or colour or anything like that.Spector comes from a mixed-race family. Her dad was Irish, her mum was ldquoblack and Cherokee. Her skin was lighter as a result, but race or colour didnrsquot figure much, she says.ldquoI thought everybody had a neighbourhood like mine, with Jewish delis and Chinese restaurants and black barbecue places. I grew up in a wonderful time. There were no gangs or dope. It was just a wonderful regular childhood. It wasnrsquot crazy.In my mind, I tell her, back then there were doo wop groups singing on every corner in Spanish Harlem. ldquoWe didnrsquot see much of the doo wops on the street, she admits. ldquoWe werenrsquot allowed to go out that much. But I love that because we had a huge family and we were protected. Thatrsquos why a lot of groups got messed up because they didnrsquot have anybody to trust. My mother travelled everywhere with us England, Scotland, America, everywhere, so it was like coming home from school. We never got into drugs and alcohol and all that stuff because your mother was there.I imagine it must have been an eye-opener when she did then go on tour and find that America wasnrsquot really like Spanish Harlem. But Spector says not. ldquoYou didnrsquot think of race, she says.That said, she does recall being on tour as part of Dick Clarkrsquos Caravan of Stars, a package put together by the American radio and TV presenter, and stopping who knows where, but definitely not Spanish Harlem, for food.One black doo wop group wouldnrsquot get off the bus, she remembers. ldquoThey said, lsquoRonnie, would you bring us back a hamburger rsquo I thought it was strange, but at  you didnrsquot pay that any attention. I didnrsquot know what I know now that they were actually afraid to get off the bus.Spector always sang. She remembers at five getting up on the coffee table at home and singing silly songs to a family audience. ldquoMy family would applaud and that stuck in my mind forever.When she was eight Spector used to go her grandmotherrsquos after school with her cousins and shersquod stand in the lobby and sing. ldquoIt was the echo in that hallway that made me feel like, I can really sing. Irsquom like eight or nine years old and Irsquom singing Frankie Lymon songs and all my cousins are backing me up with all the doo wop stuff and thatrsquos my first memory of saying lsquoI can sing.rsquoIn  Frankie Lymon ndash a Harlem boy, a boy destined for self-destruction, a boy who would OD on heroin at the age of  ndash released an album entitled At the London Palladium. She loved it, loved Frankiersquos voice. A few years later The Ronettes would be at the Palladium themselves.When Spector was  years old The Ronettes played the Apollo amateur night. ldquoMy mother would say to me, lsquoIf they like you yoursquove got it made,they donrsquot, finish your schoolwork.rsquoldquoThey loved me, so I knew that I would be a somebody in the business. I didnrsquot know how or when or who.The when was , the who Phil Spector, the how was singing Be My Baby.Other hits would follow. Baby I Love You, Walking in the Rain, most notably. The sixties had started, pop music in all its immediacy and innocence was in full bloom and The Ronettes were part of that. ldquoWe looked dferent from everybody . We had our own hair when most groups wore wigs.Success meant access. Spector met the Beatles, toured with the Stones. These days she lives just  minutes away from Keith Richards. She met him a month ago when she was going into her dentist and he was coming out.ldquoHis daughter was with him. Hersquos a changed man from that seventies era and whatever they were going through. Hersquos a great dad.Read More: Jenna Reid on launching album Working Hands at Celtic ConnectionsRonnie, I say, who was your favourite Beatle  ldquoJohn. As simple as that. He was so nice, and his mind was really intact. He knew what he wanted to do, knew what he wanted to write. We were friends. He took me to Carnaby Street and showed me where to get the T-shirts and the boots. Irsquod come back to America looking all English.ldquoHe was really my favourite one. We dated a couple of times. He took me to a couple of clubs and I remember him leaning over to me and saying, lsquoRonnie, sing a little bit of Be My Baby in my ear.rsquo And I sang, lsquoThe night we met I needed you so helliprsquo I looked over and he had passed out.Good memories. There are bad memories too. The fairy-tale le she was leading took a grim turn when she married Phil Spector. She met the producer, the ldquofirst tycoon of teenwhen she was . He made her a star and then he took it all away from her.The day after their wedding, she wrote in her  memoir Be My Baby: How I Survived Mascara, Miniskirts and Madness, she woke up to see men erecting barbed wire and gates around the Spector mansion in Beverley Hills.In the years that followed she found herself trapped at home by a controlling, abusive, paranoid man. He robbed her of performing, robbed her of her voice .The story has the odd black comic edge. When she did get permission to leave the house she had to drive in a car with a blow-up Phil Spector doll in the back. But her account of those years when published is mostly pure horror show. In the end she had to sneak out of the house and flee with the help of her mother.If anything, her memoir might have downplayed things. In  in an ultimately unsuccessful bid for unpaid royalties, Spector would claim in court that her husband pulled a gun on her during their marriage. In  Spector was found guilty of the murder of Lana Clarkson in Spectorrsquos home.Perhaps, given everything, we shouldnrsquot be surprised that she doesnrsquot want to talk about any of this now.ldquoEverybody knows that story. It wasnrsquot a relationship. I wrote a book about it. Itrsquos been well over  years since I left. I prefer the music we made together to speak rather than dwell on the negative, she says when I tentatively broach the subject.ldquoAs a matter of fact, that made me more positive today. All the hell I went through made me the woman I am today. I dusted myself off and went on with it. When I was there I wasnrsquot singing and that was my passion and without my singing it wasnrsquot even a world I was living in. It was hell.ldquoThatrsquos why I love the #MeToo movement now. I wish they had it in the sixties. Because it was a manrsquos world back then. Men were producers. Men were writers. We were like employees rather than artists.ldquoSo now my le is great. I have no regrets about het past because it made me the woman I am today. Period, Teddy.Indeed. So, letrsquos celebrate that. Because this is the story of a woman who is a survivor, a woman who put the past behind her, who married againand who still gets up on stage at the age of  and sings those old songs and takes as much pleasure from doing so as she did  years ago. More maybe.ldquoI feel grown up when Irsquom singing now. I donrsquot feel like a little girl, she says.ldquoIrsquoll tell you something Teddy,I thought something years ago that the crowd would be going crazy over me more now than they did then I would think you were crazy Ronnie, but they really are.ldquoI get crowds who are young, middle and old. Itrsquos so amazing to me to look out in the audience and see all these young girls with the beehive hairstyle and the eyeliner just like me. Itrsquos amazing.Itrsquos an idea she s to again and again. ldquoIrsquove never stopped loving it. Itrsquos my passion. Itrsquos what I do. Itrsquos what I wake up in the morning for.Boom hellip boom, boom.Ronnie Spector and the Ronettes play the Old Fruitmarket, Glasgow on Wednesday as part of Celtic Connections.RONNIE SPECTOR ON THE MUSIC INDUSTRY TODAYldquoItrsquos amazing now women are writing for themselves. Now itrsquos Taylor Swt, people like that, who write for themselves now. Back then, men made all the money.ldquoYou couldnrsquot even write for yourself andyou did you didnrsquot get any credit back then. If you put certain words in a song you didnrsquot get any credit. So, now women are really making their own money and not depending on the producers or the record companies to make them millions. And that to me is so great, I canrsquot tell you.

title: doug-marr-teachers-may-find-public-dont-support-strikes
story: Additionally, teaching has become progressively more dficult. Challenging pupil behaviour, frequent changes to curriculum and assessment have contributed to stress and workload. Smaller budgets mean doing more with less.The perception that teachers are overworked and underpaid has impacted on recruitment. Nearly all councils have multiple vacancies. Head teacher posts that once would have attracted double digit applications have become hard to fill.Unsurprisingly, teachers have become restless and vocal as they see their salaries fall in real terms. Large demonstrations and near-unanimous rejection of a % increase by Educational Institute of Scotlandmembers were clear signs of the way the wind was blowing. The decision by the EIS Council to ballot members on strike action comes as no surprise.Teachers have a case for a rise but, then again, so have many other public sector workers. Threatening strike action can be a useful bargaining strategy, but teachers and their leaders need to ponder further on its effectiveness and consequences.To paraphrase LP Hartley, the past was a dferent country and indeed, we did do things dferently there. The present social, political and economic climate is very dferent to that of the s and s. Take, for example the number of days lost to strikes. From the early s until the mid-s around  million working days were lost each year. In  the number was ,.That is largely due to the decline in union membership and influence. Additionally, unions have recognised that strike action is rarely effective. Teaching unions have generally bucked the trend and teachers continue to form a largely unionised profession. The relative strength and solidarity of the teaching unions may well be fuelling their apparent readiness to act. Nevertheless, like Marty McFly, teachers are in real danger of being transported back to the future.Very few of those to be balloted would have been involved in the prolonged industrial action of the s and s. That lack of personal experience may well contribute to strong support for strike action. Those of us, however, who lived and worked through those years remember what it was like and the lasting damage it did to the profession and, more importantly, to the youngsters who were in our care.Back then, teachers generally managed to keep parents on side. The strikes and school closures were only part of widespread action by many groups including miners, dockers, transport workers and large swathes of the public sector. It is questionable , in the current climate of austerity and post-Brexit uncertainty, parents will be as supportive. Many of them have suffered reductions in their own spending power and standard of living. They are unlikely to view teachers as a special case especiallyincurring additional expense for child care.Teachers might also wish to consider the moral imperative. Presumably we all entered the profession because of our passionate belief in the le changing potential of education. If so, can reducing young peoplersquos le chances be justied  Surely, very few teachers would argue that these youngsters are mere collateral damage. It was particularly dispiriting to hear one union leader threaten sustained strike action in Government ministersrsquo constituencies. To target particular children because of where they live would be despicable and unacceptable.During the disputes of the s I continued to run a school football team. I recall being berated by a delegation of colleagues, one of whom asked, ldquoWhose side are you on  Up until that time I had never considered that there were sides in education. I naiumlvely believed we were all on the youngstersrsquo side.Hopefully, unions and the Government will recognise that they are both on the youngstersrsquo side. Teachers deserve a rise but it mustnrsquot be our young people who foot the bill. A decent increase spread over two years may be a way out. Sure, it will cost, but not as much as sacricing another generation of young people and their prospects.

title: paul-hutcheon-delaying-brexit-is-vital-if-no-deal-departure-is-to-avoided
story: IT would not take a clairvoyant to predict that the UK is facing the most serious rupture since the second world war in fewer than  days.Here is how it might play out. By mid-March, Theresa May has successfully headed off a softer Brexit proposed by a coalition of MPs and defeated plans for second referendum by exploiting Labour isions.With the country hurtling towards a no-deal departure, the Prime Minister secures concessions from European partners and puts a revised deal in front of the Commons which wins over some Tory doubters.Labour, the Liberal Democrats and the SNP oppose the new draft, but May is confident support from the Democratic Unionist Party and Tory colleagues will suffice. On the day, a hard core of Brexiteers who still have misgivings derail the plan and defeat the Prime Minister. As a result of Westminster paralysis, the UK crashes out of the European Union without a deal on March th.The consequences for the UK economy and society are immediate. Excessive form-filling at ports in the south of England has led to queues of more than  miles in the UK and France. Farmers are panicking about the lack of seasonal harvest workers and warning about the impact of World Trade Organisation rules on exporting their products.Hotels, pubs and restaurants are also complaining about the effect of no deal on their ability to recruit staff and shoppers staring at empty shelves in supermarkets. Car manufacturers announce plans to relocate from the UK and the financial services sector loses vital passporting rights.But it is the strain on the NHS that is causing the most anger. The cost of medicines is to rise sharply and the Health Secretary has conceded that delays will affect the importation of le-saving drugs. All waiting times targets are suspended for five years and thousands of UK nationals in the EU are unsurethey can receive any care.A no-deal Brexit, and the chaos many predict will ensue, is a live prospect because of the terms laid out in the Lisbon Treaty on how to leave the European Union. Once a country invokes Article  ndash the beginning of the withdrawal process ndash the same state has two years to negotiate a deal. The UK departs at the end of March.As we reveal today, key parts of Scottish society have major reservations about the Brexit impasse and the prospect of no deal. Bodies such as the Scottish Trades Union Congress, the Scottish Council for Voluntary Organisations and the Scottish Chambers of Commerce support an extension of Article .Civic Scotland is backed up by political muscle. First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, as well as Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie and Scottish Greens co-convener Patrick Harvie, are demanding that Brexit is delayed. Collectively these parties represent a clear majority of MSPs at Holyrood. The Prime Minister is under pressure to heed these calls.The argument for an extension is multi-faceted. The  referendum was won by Leave, but even the most passionate Brexiteer would have to concede there is nothing written in the stars about March . Supporters of the intervention believe it is more important to get a good deal than fixate on a specic date in the calendar.There are also political reasons for a delay. The Leave campaignrsquos specic promises have been pored over, scrutinised and mocked, but eurosceptics consistently said the UK would get some form of deal from the EU. Crashing out was never part of the offer ndash regardless of what we have heard in recent days and weeks. An extension would not contradict the verdict delivered in the referendum.But it is the potential economic damage that is fuelling calls for a push back. According to the Confederation of British Industry, no deal would cause GDP to shrink by up to % and put thousands of jobs at risk. Government analysis claimed the GDP hit could be .% over  years. A contraction of this sort would inevitably lead to huge reductions in public spending.Seeking an extension is within the gt of the House of Commons. Senior Labour figures seem broadly sympathetic and the Prime Minister has pointedly refused to rule out a delay.However, as with much of the Brexit melodrama, the key factor is the internal politics of the Tory party. The Prime Minister may recognise the move is inevitable, but she is worried about the cries of betrayal from right-wing colleagues who will see an extension as a plot to stay in the EU. The clock is ticking.

title: snp-to-select-candidates-for-european-elections-in-case-brexit-is-delayed
story: Nicola Sturgeonrsquos party will vet hopefuls in the next few weeks, while the Scottish Greens and Liberal Democrats are also exploring the idea in light of the current Brexit chaos.A senior SNP source said the move would send a ldquopowerful signal that scrapping Brexit is becoming a serious option.The UK is set to leave the EU on March th, with or without a deal on the terms of departure.The next elections to the European Parliament are scheduled for May, but the UK voters will not elect any MEPs as the country is scheduled to have left the EU.However, given that the UK Governmentrsquos draft withdrawal plan was comprehensively rejected by MPs last year, a range of options have moved into view.These include a no deal Brexit, which will occurMPs fail to raty an agreement struck with EU negotiators, and a second referendum.It is also possible for the UK to delay Brexit by requesting an extension to the Article  process which will lead to the UK leaving in March.And, as a result of a court case brought about by Scottish politicians, the UK can cancel Brexit by revoking Article .One of the lsquodelayrsquo models is extending the leave date by a few months, by which point the new round MEPs will have taken their seats.It would also be possible, but politically harder, to extend Article  for a substantially longer period.At a recent meeting of the SNPrsquos national executive committee , senior councillor Chris McEleny, who has contested his partyrsquos depute leadership election, is said to have raised the issue of the next European elections.It is understood he said the SNP, which favours a second referendum on leaving the EU, should select MEP candidates because it is possible Brexit may not go ahead.A source said: ldquoChris said thatArticle  is revoked or extended then Scotland will still require representation in the European Parliament, and so it would be diligent to have candidates in place.Keith Brown, the SNPrsquos Depute Leader, confirmed the move to this newspaper:ldquoThe SNP is open to candidate applications for the  European Parliament election. We are working on the basis that the party will be vetting and selecting people to stand in the coming weeks.ldquoAs we are calling for the extension of Article  negotiation period between the UK and European Union - to avoid the clf edge of a no deal at the the end of March - it is vital we prepare for such a sht.ldquoI look forward to seeing who comes forward from the wealth of talent that exists in our mass membership ranks."A spokesperson for the Scottish Greens said: "With the deal dead and a Commons majority against No Deal, staying in has gone from a pipe dream to one of the most viable options. Preparing for a potential election is both the most responsible thing to do and a clear statement of intent. We intend to beat Brexit and and were increasingly confident that we can."A Scottish Liberal Democrat spokesperson said: ldquoWe are making the preparations necessary to enable us to ballot all our members to select our Euro candidatesthere is to be a European election.In a recent article, the Institute for Government think tank laid out four options for the UK continuing to have some form of representation in Brussels during an extension period.One of the stated options is to elect new MEPs until the end of the Article  period. ldquoThe UK would hold European Parliament elections this year, although not necessarily at the same time as the rest of the EU. This option would only make sensethere was an extended extension.

title: civic-scotland-brexit-must-be-delayed-and-chaotic-no-deal-avoided
story: Leaders in the business, trades union, charity and higher education sectors are behind calls to pause what promises to be the biggest economic change in the UK in over  years.Their call, which is echoed by the SNP, Scottish Liberal Democrats and the Greens, comes as the Prime Minister plans to unveil her Brexit "plan B" to MPs tomorrow.Under the terms of the  Lisbon Treaty, the UK is scheduled to leave the EU on March , two years after Theresa May invoked the so-called Article  which sets a time limit on negotiations.However, with Parliament rejecting the withdrawal plan presented by Theresa May, the prospect of the UK coming out of the -member bloc without a deal grows by the day.Various reports have warned that no deal would have negative economic consequences for the UK, with shortages of medicines and huge tailbacks at ports being predicted.Although March  is the official leaving date, an extension to the process can be granted by EU member statesthe UK makes a request.A range of high-profile bodies in Scotland has intervened by calling for Brexit to be delayed. Anna Fowlie, chief executive of the Scottish Council for Voluntary Organisations , which has around , members, said:ldquoAfter two years, we find ourselves on the brink of exiting the EU without a withdrawal agreement that both the UK Parliament and the EU can sign up to.ldquoThere is therefore no choice but to seek agreement with the EU to extend Article  to allow time for a second EU referendum to take place.Liz Cameron, director and chief executive of the Scottish Chamber of Commerce, said: ldquoThe rationale for a delay to the Article  timeline is growing each and every day in our business communities.ldquoAn extension to Article  would, first and foremost, avoid a no deal outcome on March , but it would also acknowledge that neither business nor government are prepared for such a scenario.Colin Borland, director of Devolved Nations at the Federation of Small Businesses , which has around , members, said: ldquoThis longer window could give Scottish business a much-needed opportunity to prepare while taking the fever out of the public debate.And David Watt, executive director of the Institute of Directors in Scotland, said business leaders are ldquovery concerned about a no-deal Brexit: ldquoWith all of this in mind, the inevitable conclusion is to extend Article . It may be the only option to ensure a deal and a reasonable transition period.Grahame Smith, general secretary of the Scottish Trades Union Congress, which represents around , trade unionists, also backs an extension, as does GMB Scotland Secretary Gary Smith.Professor Sir Anton Muscatelli, principal of Glasgow University, is also strongly in favour of hitting the pause button as a way of delivering another referendum."With the Prime Ministerrsquos deal dead and Parliament in gridlock, there is only one way out ndash that is to request an extension to Article , and call a Peoplersquos Vote, he said.He added that an extension would ldquoappear the only opportunity to avoid the chaos of a No Deal outcome.In todayrsquos Herald on Sunday, the senior civic figures are joined by First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie and Scottish Green co-convener Patrick Harvie.It also comes after three former Prime Ministers ndash John Major, Tony Blair and Gordon Brown ndash called on Article  to be either extended or revoked.Major, who was a Tory PM between  and , has said revoking Article  is the ldquoonly sensible course, as a no-deal Brexit would be ldquomorally reprehensible.Blair said he would be discussing the terms of an extension with the EUhe was still in Government, while Brown called for Brexit to be delayed by a year.Mayrsquos minority administration is opposed to an extension, but the Prime Minister has not ruled it out.However, the move would anger her pro-Brexit backbenchers and likely lead to further Cabinet resignations.Boris Johnson, the Brexiteer who quit as Mayrsquos Foreign Secretary in protest at one version of her deal, warned against an extension:"It would be so utterly pathetic that I do think it would not only cause widespread international dismay but also reinforce peoples view that there is some sort of plot at Westminster to stop this thing .":

title: Iain Macwhirter  MPs must work together to unblock Brexit  or they   ll open the way for authoritarians
story: So, we at least have breathing space, a pause, a moment for reflection. My own wish would be for MPs to seize the moment and vote to revoke Article  altogether. MPs have the power to stop the clock for good, thanks to the good works of legally-minded MPs like the SNPrsquos Joanna Cherry.Staying in the EU is the only sure way to stop the endless arguments about Canada plus, Norway plus, customs union, Irish backstop, regulatory alignment, maximum facilitation and all the rest of the gubbins thatrsquos been occupying our addled brains for the last two-and-a-half years. However, this isnrsquot going to happen.And Irsquod have to agree that it would be undemocratic for MPs to simply reverse the result of the  referendum by revoking A. It may be that Parliament has the power and the constitutional right to do so: referendums are only advisory. But it would leave so much unpleasantness that British politics would be soured for decades. There would have to be a referendum.This is where my unease turns to genuine anxiety. I have a horrible feeling that Labourrsquos Diane Abbott was right on Question Time this week when she said: ldquoBe careful what you wish for. She agrees with Nigel Farage that a repeat referendum is likely to endorse no-deal Brexit, perhaps by an even greater margin than in .Evenit left us with a mirror-image result, with say % Remain against % Leave, that would itself be a disaster because it would have no legitimacy. Yes, some opinion polls say Remain would win a comfortable majority, but they said that last time.The Brexiteers are already field-testing their slogans on social media. The frontrunner is ldquoTell Them Again, which may not be as resonant as ldquoTake Back Control but is still pretty hot. It surfs on the very widespread disgust and alienation that many ordinary people feel about the political elite. It appeals to democratic injustice: how dare the globalists ignore the result of , which David Cameron promised would be for keeps What would Remainrsquos slogan be  Itrsquos likely to be a repeat of the Project Fear line which failed dismally in . ldquoDonrsquot put your childrenrsquos prosperity at risk, perhaps, or ldquoThink Twice Think Jobs. But what many pro-Europeans fail to grasp ndash and this applied to the Unionists in the Scottish independence referendum ndash is that it ISNrsquoT the economy, stupid. Brexit voters donrsquot just make their decisions on the basis of economic rationality, as seen from the CBI and corporate Britain.People are always motivated more by emotion than numbers ndash on what they believe to be morally right. The sense that working-class people have lost control is a very potent mobiliser.As in war ndash and it is remarkable how much Brexit mythology harks back to World War Two ndash people are quite willing to sacrice some comfort for what they believe in.I may think they are mistaken. As with the people who supported Donald Trump because he promised to Make America Great Again, and bring back the jobs, I think Brexit voters have been sold a  prospectus by politicians who do not have the best interests of working people at their hearts.But that isnrsquot really the point. I can well understand the sense of injustice felt by people who have been left behind by global capitalism. They want to kick the system, and the referendum gave them a chance to do it. They need a very strong reason not to kick the metropolitans again. Only Labour can provide that reason, and Jeremy Corbyn has been singularly reluctant to do so.His refusal even to meet Theresa May was irresponsible in this climate. It may have allowed him to avoid coming off the fence, but it looked petty and weak. Corbyn should have gone in guns blazing, demanded that she drop the red lines, and then mobilised Labour for either rejoining the single market or for a referendum.Single market membership has always been the logic of Labourrsquos position, even though Corbyn usually refers to a ldquopermanent customs union. Only by joining the European Economic Area could Labour deliver friction-free trade, and protect environmental standards and workers rights. People say that Norway has blocked the UKrsquos entry to the European Economic Area, but this is not true. The Norwegian PM, Erna Solberg, has repeatedly made clear that Norway would have severe reservations ndashwho wouldnrsquot  ndash but would not block UK membership.This is because the EEA is essentially a Brussels creation. It was set up as a halfway house to membership of the EU back in  when a number of countries were uneasy about joining the political institutions of Europe. The EEA is just the European Single Market under another name.Brussels endorses British membership of the EEA, and this economic arrangement has a number of advantages over Mayrsquos deal. Therersquos no need for an Irish backstop no membership of the CAP and the Common Fisheries Policy no direct jurisdiction of the European Court and it costs less than EU membership. Of course, it does not bring the full benefits of EU membership. Britain would become a ldquorule taker on trade. But the EEA does not preclude future membership of the European Union. Norway, or any other member of the EEA, can opt for full membership at any time. And unlike the backstop, countries can leave the EEA after one year.Membership of the single market also means accepting freedom of movement, which is why it may well be rejected by Parliament. But it is the only option that has a snowballrsquos chance of getting a majority,Labour were to seriously support it. ldquoNorway plus, as itrsquos called, has more support than a repeat referendum. Fewer than  Labour MPs have called for a Peoples Vote, and only  Conservatives. The SNP has decided to throw its lot in with a repeat referendum, despite having argued convincingly for the single market for the last two years. But that isnrsquot enough.To repeat. Were it left to me, I would revoke Article  tomorrow. I just want this madness to stop. But given the metrics in Parliament, we have to look at the least worst options, as the Labour-supporting commentator Owen Jones put it last week. Mayrsquos deal is dead. MPs owe it to the country, and to themselves, to find some compromise that works. Perhaps that can only be achieved with a referendum. ButMPs fail this week, they risk destroying respect for parliamentary democracy, and opening the way for a more authoritarian form of political leadership.

title: alyn-smith-eu-member-says-the-only-way-to-stop-this-madness-is-not-to-leave-eu-at-all
story: After the last few weeks of drama it is easy to be lose focus. Mrs Mayrsquos remarkable achievement of winning a party leadership vote then a vote of confidence while simultaneously heading the first UK Government in history to be found in contempt of Parliament and suffering the biggest-ever defeat is enough to make anyonersquos head spin.So plotting the next few weeks and months will be dficult, but there are a few gravitational forces that cannot be denied. Firstly, the clock is ticking. Unless something  actively happens, the UK and Scotland with it will leave the EU at pmon March . All this ldquotherersquos no majority in the Commons for No Deal is entirely meaningless, much like the iceberg did not actually bear the Titanic any ill will ndash exit will happen unless they actively do something to stop it.Secondly, Mayrsquos ldquodeal is only to exit. The future is dealt with only in an aspirational Political Declaration which is not worthless, but not binding either. So all the bumping of gums by MPs about Norway plus, Canada minus or upside-down Lichtenstein is all so much puff ndash these negotiations will only start after the exit. If we exit with a deal then a transition period kicks in where EU law will continue to apply as we try to negotiate the future relationship. Basically wersquoll have as little idea of the future, except wersquoll be outside the EU.SoBrexit happens, a ldquosoft Brexit where the UK remains in the single market and the customs union is undoubtedly the least damaging aspiration. This is why the Scottish Government and others have proposed it as a potential ldquoless bad option in the spirit of trying to find solutions, but they have also been clear EU membership is the best option.My concern is that there may well be a majority in the House of Commons for a Norway-style aspiration, but that it will be as unsustainable as all the other pipe dreams and in reality offers no stability at all. It would not withstand its first crisis, which would come all the harder because by then we would have lost the chance to avert it, having left the EU.So letrsquos take a look at it. EFTArsquos own website explains that ldquothe EEA EFTA states have little influence on the decision-making phase on the EU side. Instead, they focus on ldquodecision shaping. This involves informal consultations, attendance at some committees, and submission of views in generally short ldquocomments papers.This is not nothing, but it is light years from the power we have now in council and the European Parliament, and votes for ministers and the UKrsquos  MEPs.The term ldquoVassal State is overblown and grievously offensive to many EU states who actually were until recently, but the reality is that the amount of influence we would have is really very limited. From day one the deal would be ripe for destabilisation by unsatisfied Brexit ultras and their allies.The current members of the EEA and EFTA have spent many decades building up how it works they know the compromises and the shortcomings. The UK political class and administrative machinery are wholly unprepared for the reality that being a rule-taker would bring.You can imagine the mischief the Brexit ultras would make. In a world where outrage can be whipped up over rules on lightbulbs, kettles and toasters, theyrsquod be braying for vetoes to be used at the slightest hint of a controversial EU law. Of course, they would move on to attacking membership of the EEA on this basis.Some already see the EEA as a way to gradually move to a hard Brexit by stealth, so eventhe arrangement survived first contact it is unlikely it would be remotely stable in the medium to long-term.Itrsquos a measure of just how damaging Brexit is that the very best alternative is still much worse than EU membership. It still brings considerable economic shocks, has a considerable price tag in terms of ongoing contributions to EU programmes, gives little real extra in terms of control, and reduces our influence in Europe and the world dramatically.Of the options we face, all of which have signicant problems, the best deal remains and always has been EU membership.Until March, the door remains open to maintaining that and we should not allow ourselves to settle for unstable halfway houses for the lack of a bit of intellectual honesty and political courage.The reality is that soft Brexit will inevitably become hard Brexit because the Brexit ultras have no desire to compromise. In the face of this the House of Commons only has one real choice: Remain.Yes, it would be messy and yes, it will take courage, but even the best alternative is far worse.Alyn Smith is a Scottish politician, and Scottish National Party MEP for Scotland

title: article-50-explained
story: Itrsquos a formal legal process that had never before been used until the UK invoked it on March , .The article - only  words long - forms part of the Lisbon Treaty, drawn up in December of  as part of a bid to make the EU ldquomore democratic, more transparent and more efficient. Signed by the heads of state and EU governments, the treaty includes the article, which is a basic five-point plan for any country wishing to depart the European Union.It states: ldquoAny member state may decide to withdraw from the union in accordance with its own constitutional requirements.And its only real quantiable detail is a provision that provides negotiators with two years from the date of article  notication to conclude new arrangements.Failure to do so means the state falls out of the EU with no new provisions in place.And so, when the UK told the EU it was leaving, it meant it would no longer "participate in the discussions of the European Council or Council or in decisions concerning it.But two and a half years on from the vote to leave and it seems the UK is no further forward.So could the article be revoked Under its wording, the government can obtain an extension from the European Council, provided that the other  countries accept unanimously.And after the Brexit deal was rejected, the Committee on Exiting the European Union yesterday saidParliament could not agree on a way forward by the March  departure day, lawmakers should be able to vote on whether to extend the article  negotiation period.Last night, it was reported that European officials were indeed examining plans to delay Brexit until  after France and Germany indicated their willingness to extend negotiations due to the turmoil in Great Britain.Chancellor Philip Hammond had raised the possibility of an extension on Tuesday, saying in a call with business leaders that a ldquono-deal Brexit could be avoided.According to the CBI, he outlined how the  March date might be postponed.On Monday, Theresa May declined to categorically rule out an extension, stressing she wishes to deliver a ldquosmooth and orderly departure.But as the last two and a half years have shown, nothing is ldquosmooth and orderly about Brexit.

title: 10-voices-tell-herald-on-sunday-why-we-should-delay-brexit
story: ldquoArticle  must now be extended. That is the best way to stop the clock and take away any risk of the UK crashing out of the European Union without a deal at the end of March ndash which would be devastating to Scotlandrsquos economy, businesses and communities.ldquoOnce that extension has been agreed, the UK Government should bring forward legislation to give people a say in another referendum. The Prime Minister has had two-and-a-half years to come up with a credible, workable Brexit plan and we are no further forward, so now it is time for other options to be put on the table.Liz Cameron OBE, Director  Chief Executive, Scottish Chambers of CommerceldquoThe rationale for a delay to the Article  timeline is growing each and every day in our business communities. An extension to Article  would, first and foremost, avoid a no-deal outcome on March , but it would also acknowledge that neither business nor government are prepared for such a scenario. Our firms still lack the clear, precise information that would enable them to adapt to new trading conditions, and businesses do not have confidence that government is ready to successfully manage any disruption that may arise.ldquoWhile an extension to Article  prolongs uncertainty for business, it would also avoid the clear danger that a no-deal exit on March  poses to business, communities, and the UK economy.ldquoFollowing the defeat of the Prime Ministerrsquos Brexit agreement, businesses will be weighing up the least bad option. For many firms, extending the timeline of business uncertainty a bit longer will be a price worth paying in order to avoid the damage and confusion that a no-deal Brexit would inflict on businesses and communities.Professor Sir Anton Muscatelli, principal of Glasgow University"With the Prime Ministerrsquos deal dead and Parliament in gridlock, there is only one way out ndash that is to request an extension to Article , and call a Peoplersquos Vote."The EU has been clear that it would be prepared to accept a short extension to Article this facilitated a second referendum in advance of the European Parliament elections, and ndash given that the Prime Minister has been unable to secure an acceptable deal and Parliament is clearly unable to agree on an acceptable alternative ndash doing so would appear the only opportunity to avoid the chaos of a no-deal outcome."Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie RennieldquoA no-deal Brexit would be devastating, with British exports snarled up in bureaucratic form-filling and potentially shortages of food and medicine.ldquoIt baffles me that any government that seriously claimed to have its citizens interests at heart could contemplate this. Thatrsquos why it is essential that the Prime Minister ndash or Parliament ndash withdraw Article .ldquoExtending Article  would give the time for Labour and the Conservatives to take a long hard look at themselves and admit that Brexit is a disaster. It would also allow us the time to legislate for a Peoplersquos Vote with the option of remaining in the EU.Patrick Harvie, co-convener of the Scottish GreensldquoFollowing this weekrsquos events, the -week timetable isnrsquot remotely credible. With no clarity about plan B, no willingness in the EU to renegotiate, and no serious support for the chaos of the clf-edge, the Article  process must be extended or revoked."We have more than enough reasons for a Peoplersquos Vote ndash the Leave campaignrsquos  promises and outright lies, the findings that it broke electoral law, the dark money scandal and the deadlock at Westminster. We must let the voters cancel this self-destructive process, and remain members of the EU with all the benefits that guarantees.David Watt, executive director of IoD ScotlandldquoThe IoD is now speaking to its members to gauge what they would like to see politicians do next. Business leaders in general are very concerned about a no-deal Brexit and its implications especially the lack of preparation time."Many will find themselves at a clf edge over tarfs, logistics and funding, not to mention air traffic and on-time supply of parts. The biggest concern is staff, especially the uncertainty and cost facing even long-term EU citizens living and working in Scotland."With all of this in mind, the inevitable conclusion is to extend Article . It may be the only option to ensure a deal and a reasonable transition period.Grahame Smith, general secretary of the STUCldquoTheresa Mayrsquos deal is dead in the water so MPs must now focus on what happens next. Crashing out of the EU in a no-deal Brexit is a catastrophe for workers. After a decade of austerity and with living standards already under pressure, workers simply will not tolerate any more economic pain."With Parliament so ided the only sure way to avoid no-deal is to extend the Article  process. This allows time to sort the mess created by this incompetent Government and gives people the chance to have their say through a general election or Peoplersquos Vote.Colin Borland, director of devolved nations at the Federation of Small Businesses "With only one in seven Scottish small businesses preparing for no-deal, extending Article  may become necessary. But itrsquoll only be worth buying extra timewe can break the deadlock. That means cross-party co-operation and compromise."With business confidence plummeting, our politicians need to put aside dferences, for the wellbeing of their communitiesnothing . During any extension ndash say until the newly elected MEPs take their seats on July  ndash we must secure a transitional deal."This longer window could give Scottish business a much-needed opportunity to prepare while taking the fever out of the public debate."Gary Smith, Scotland Secretary of the GMB trade unionldquoThe extension of Article  is essential because a no-deal Brexit would be disastrous for the Scottish economy.ldquoOutside the political bubble, industries are stockpiling and the price of commodities and raw materials are rising. Itrsquos fuel for a slump and an inflation hike which would hammer jobs and households."Meanwhile, the loss of the EIB [European Investment Bank] will hit future investment in Scotlandrsquos infrastructure hard ndash a generation lost."There is no good news here. Scotland is going to suffer serious blows but short of remaining in the EU we need more time to try to mitigate the inevitable damage.Anna Fowlie, chief executive of the Scottish Council for Voluntary Organisations ldquoSCVO continues to advocate continued EU membership. However, the UK Government is pressing ahead with exiting from the EU having triggered Article  without knowing what it wanted to negotiate."After two years, we find ourselves on the brink of exiting the EU without a withdrawal agreement that both the UK Parliament and the EU can sign up to. There is therefore no choice but to seek agreement with the EU to extend Article  to allow time for a second EU referendum to take place."The questions on the ballot should be agreed with the devolved parliaments and should include remain as an option. If we donrsquot do this, Scotland and the rest of the UK will be pushed over the clf into an unknown situation that could be disastrous for our country, particularly our most vulnerable citizens.:

title: burns-night-whisky-cocktail-recipes
